Search for Buildings on Campus
Your password must have at least 6 characters, contain at least 1 uppercase letter, 1 digit, and 1 special symbol
Your location services are required for LionGps and are currently not enabled. Please re-enable them to continue using the app

80 Claremont is a 5-story building on the southwest corner of Union Theological Seminary\'s quadrangle on 120th Street between Broadway and Claremont Avenue. The building was constructed in the Gothic style. Columbia took possession of the building through a 99 year lease in 2005 following $4 million in renovations as part of a short-term expansion plan that also includes the lease of Knox Hall. 80 Claremont is home to the Religion Department and Science and Technology Ventures. Religion gained 70 percent more space than it had in Kent Hall, while EALAC and MEALAC expanded into the vacated space in Kent.

Alfred Lerner Hall is the student center. It was built from 1996-1999, replacing Ferris Booth Hall, and is named for donor Alfred Lerner CC\'55. Lerner is notorious for its infuriating system of space-wasting and inefficient upward-spiralling ramps. The stairs in the exit stairwells are actually the quickest way to navigate Lerner. Lerner houses Ferris Booth dining hall, Blue Java cafe, the office of student life and a piano lounge
Altschul Hall is on the Barnard campus and is the home of many large lecture courses. It houses Java City on the 2nd floor
Avery Hall is home of the Graduate School of Architecture. It houses Avery Library and The Fine Arts and Architecture Library of Columbia
Barnard Hall is one of the oldest buildings on the Barnard Campus, named after the namesake of the College and Columbia President Frederick Barnard. It houses a fitness center and Streng dance studio
Broadway Hall is a dorm built in 2000 and Designed by Robert A. M. Stern, CC \'60. It houses a stargazers lounge which is at times used for classes

Butler Library is the main undergraduate and graduate research library. It ranks as among the most notable and iconic structures at Columbia. Competition for open study spaces can be fierce at Butler during midterms and finals. It houses BlueJava and a CUIT computer lab
Carman Hall was built in 1959 and is a dorm for Columbia Students. Has a reputation as a party dorm of sorts.
Casa Hispanica is beaux-arts townhouse that houses the Spanish, Portuguese, and Catalan language center
Chandler Laboratories, otherwise known as Chandler Hall, houses research labs and a handful of classrooms.

The CS Building houses the CS Department of Columbia University and is itself located inside Mudd Engineering building. Parts of the CS department are not accessible to non-CS students beyond normal working hours.
Deutsches Haus is a building devoted to the german language and the first foreign language hall established at an american university. Affiliated with the department of Germanic languages
The Diana Center is a building on Barnard College’s campus and the student center of the college. It was completed in 2010 and has some of the most striking and futuristic architecture at Columbia.
Dodge Hall is the home of the School of the Arts, the Department of Music, and the Kathyrn Bache Miller Theatre. Has a Blue Java Cafe in the lobby.

Columbia’s gym. Also known as the Marcellus Hartley Dodge Physical Fitness Center, Dodge shares its name with Dodge Hall, which has inspired decades of confusion among undergraduates. Has extensive amenities but has a reputation for being crowded during peak hours.
Earl Hall is home for the religious services and organizations of Columbia (Office of the University Chaplain).
East Campus is a dorm, reputed for its parties. If your club has a holiday gathering it will likely happen here.

Engineering Terrace is an extension to Mudd that was built behind Fairchild since there was all that extra space, anyway. The "building" houses faculty offices and little more. It is also used as a passageway to the Computer Science Building.

Faculty House is a 38,000-square-foot facility that hosts a wide variety of functions, including receptions, social events, meetings, conferences, and seminars. It houses the Ivy Lounge and a full coffee bar
Fairchild Center is a building that house’s biology labs and offices on Columbia’s campus.
Fayerweather is a building that houses the History and Sociology departments. Fayerweather was notably occupied by students during the protests of 1968.

One of the most iconic structures of Columbia’s Morningside Heights campus, Hamilton Hall houses the Office of the Core and many iconic and require Core classes, including lit hum and UW. Also houses the classics department. It also houses the cheapest coffee on campus, 25 cent coffee on the 4th floor, at the German Department. Also stairs that will break your resolve and shatter your dignity into tiny pieces.
Hartley Hall was the first dorm built on Columbia’s Morningside Heights Campus. It remains a dorm, having been renovated during the 1980s.

Havemeyer Hall is a building on the Morningside Heights Campus. It is one of the 6 original buildings of this campus and a National Historic Chemical Landmark. Many important experiments in the history of Chemistry have been conducted in Havemeyer.
The Heyman Center for the Humanities is located in East Campus (EC) and presents itself as a forum for discourse between different disciplines in the Humanities.

Horace Mann Hall share its namesake with Horace Mann School, an elite private school in the bronx. Horace Mann School was founded by President Butler, as an experimental teaching lab of Teacher’s College. Today the hall is a part of Teacher’s College, and is no longer associated with Horace Mann School.
International Affairs Building (also known colloquially as SIPA) is the home of the School of International and Public Affairs.

International House (aka I-House) is a private residence for graduate students and scholars. It has over 700 residents and is a prominent fixture of NYC’s academic and intellectual landscape. Scholars come from schools all over NYC, including Columbia.
Jerome Green is the primary building of Columbia Law School. Opinion is divided on whether it is plain ugly, or ugly in a way defended vociferously by architecture students.
John Jay Hall is a first year residence hall. It is named after founding father and alumnus John Jay. It houses John Jay cafeteria and JJs dining hall

The Journalism Building houses the school of Journalism. I mean what were you expecting? It is now referred to as Pulitzer Hall, named after the founder of the Journalism school and the namesake of the prestigious Pulitzer Prize.

Kent Hall is named after James Kent, Columbia’s first law professor, and is the current home of the Middle East, South Asian, and African Studies Department (MESAAS) and the East Asian Languages and Cultures Department (EALAC).
Knox Hall is a building on the quad of Union Theological Seminary. Columbia is currently leasing the hall from UTS.
Kraft Center, or the Kraft Center for Jewish Life, houses classrooms and club rooms.
Lewisohn Hall is home to the School of General Studies and the School of Professional Studies. It houses the GS lounge, and the creators of this very app

Low Memorial Library is the former main library of Columbia University, a position that Butler now holds. Low is now the symbolic center of campus, the home of the University’s most senior academic buildings, including the President’s Office.
Macy Hall is a building on the Teacher’s College Campus.
Mathematics predictably houses the Mathematics department.

The oldest structure on Barnard’s Campus. Looks a bit like a haunted home in Dicken’s novel. Covered in Ivy. It houses the French, Italian, Slavic languages, German, Sociology, and Psychology departments. Also the Toddler Center.
A building on Barnards campus

Morris A. Schapiro Hall, popularly known as Schapiro, is an undergraduate residence hall that mostly houses juniors in singles and sophomores in doubles. Schapiro was built in 1987 for $18m, making it the second newest residence hall after Broadway. When it was completed, Schapiro enabled Columbia to guarantee housing to all undergraduates for all 4 years for the first time in its history.
Also known as NoCo, this building serves as an interdisciplinary center for Columbia Science departments. It houses The Levien Gym, Joe Coffee, and the Science and Engineering
Home of the Philosophy department, English Department, the French Department, Student Services, and Work Study.
On 125th, Prentis Hall houses the Computer Music Center and other arts facilities.
An extension of the Journalism Building

Named after Columbia alum and acclaimed scientist Mihajlo Idvorski Pupin, Pupin Labs was the site of some of the most salient advances in science (including the first splitting of a uranium atom by Enrico Fermi).
Also known as CEPSR, this building features a huge auditorium (Davis) and offices affiliated with various engineering departments.
Schermerhorn Hall is home to many departments including Archeology, and the Geology Library
Home to the School of Social Work (duh), the Social Work Library and the Department of Statistics.
Mudd is the home of SEAS, and also the CS department (a subset of SEAS that resides in an adjoining structure).
Interfaith Chapel on Columbia’s Campus with services for numerous denominations and faiths.
A Teacher’s College academic building.
A graduate school of theology affiliated with Columbia.
Home of the Business School of Columbia University (CBS). Depressingly ugly, but at least it has an awesome library straight out of the 1970s (Watson) and a solid Deli.
An undergraduate dorm, once known as Livingston Hall.
Home of Information Technology and School of the Arts.
Part of the Law School.
Part of the Law School.
